title: Graphical Analysis - Behavior of f from f prime

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The figure above shows the graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 4, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 1, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 3 comma 4, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals 0.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 1.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 2.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="f of 2, equals 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. On what open intervals contained in <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 4, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> both decreasing and concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

The figure above shows the graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 4, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 1, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 3 comma 4, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The graph of <math alttext="f prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> has horizontal tangents at <math alttext="x equals 0.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 1.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals 2.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="f of 2, equals 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. On what open intervals contained in <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 4, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> both decreasing and concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

Find the absolute minimum value of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 4, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

Evaluate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 4, of, f of x, times f prime of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>.

The function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals x cubed, times f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="g prime of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

topic.text: 5.8: Sketching Graphs of Functions and Their Derivatives

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
